SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS WAS NONE . HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS : The patient is a 31 year old white female who presented to the Emergency Department at the Ver Medical Center with a chief complaint of diffuse abdominal pain which was periumbilical in origin . Patient had experienced periumbilical pain which was nonradiating , mild , and stable for approximately three days . In addition , she had had three days of nausea and vomiting . She complained of no dysuria and no vaginal or urinary discharge . Her last meal was on the day of admission . Her last bowel movement was two days prior to admission and her last menstrual period was on November 6 , 1997 . Patient did note some slight anorexia . PAST MEDICAL / SURGICAL HISTORY : Unremarkable . CURRENT MEDICATIONS : She took no medications . ALLERGIES : She had no known drug allergies . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : She had a temperature of 100.1 degrees Fahrenheit , heart rate 115 , and blood pressure 139/89 . HEENT : Oropharynx was clear , extraocular movements were intact , and pupils were equal , round , and reactive to light . CHEST : Lungs were clear to auscultation . HEART : Regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs , rubs , or gallops . ABDOMEN : Positive bowel sounds , nondistended , no hepatosplenomegaly , no costovertebral angle tenderness , no hernia , and no rebound or guarding . There was mild right lower quadrant and left lower quadrant tenderness and no masses palpable . RECTAL : Nontender and hemoccult negative . PELVIC : Examination showed no masses and mild cervical motion tenderness . EXTREMITIES : No cyanosis , clubbing , or edema . NEUROLOGICAL : No focal deficits . LABORATORY EXAMINATION : Studies revealed that chemistries were within normal limits , white blood cell count was 20.8000 , hematocrit was 38 , and platelets were 272,000 . KUB was performed in the Emergency Room which showed dilated loops of small bowel with no air fluid levels . In addition , an ultrasound was performed of the right lower quadrant which showed no evident appendix . The pelvis and pelvic structures were normal and there was a normal gallbladder and kidneys seen on the right . Chest x-ray was unremarkable , urinalysis was negative , and beta HCG was negative . HOSPITAL COURSE : The patient was admitted to the hospital with a principle diagnosis of likely perforated appendicitis . She was admitted and put on intravenous antibiotics with plan of obtaining an abdominopelvic CT scan . On the day of admission , an abdominopelvic CAT scan was obtained which showed dilated loops of fluid filled bowel and colon in the right lower quadrant . The colon was decompressed distally and there was no contrast seen in the lower intestine . This was thought to represent at least a partial small bowel obstruction or possibly an ileus . There were some bubbles of free air which were thought to be extraluminal . The primary diagnosis at that time was complicated or perforated appendicitis with partial small bowel obstruction . A delayed CT scan was planned in order to follow contrast through the lower intestine and on this delayed CT scan , contrast was seen passing distally through the lower intestine . At this time , on hospital day one with a diagnosis of perforated appendicitis and right lower quadrant phlegmon , it was felt that this course of action would be to either proceed with surgery or attempt to stabilize the patient with intravenous fluids , antibiotics , and possibly wait for six weeks for elective appendectomy . The patient was started on triple antibiotics of ampicillin , Gentamicin , and Flagyl , kept NPO , and serial examinations were obtained . Over the first three hospital days , her white blood cell count fell to under 10,000 . Sips of clear liquids were started and were tolerated without complication . Patient 's physical examination remained relatively unremarkable , however , she began to develop slight abdominal distention . After the patient was tolerating clear sips , she was given one liter of Golytely with the intention of clearing out her bowel in case surgery was needed . Repeat CAT scan was obtained on hospital day five . This CAT scan was relatively unchanged showing matted loops of bowel in the right lower quadrant . The appendix was not well visualized . The repeat CT scan also showed contained fluid collections in the pelvis and these were not felt to be communicating . These were also not felt to be collections which could be drained by interventional radiology . Given the progression of the patient 's CAT scan and the relative nonprogression of her clinical course , the decision was made after discussion with the patient to proceed with exploratory laparotomy and likely ileocecectomy with secondary wound closure . Patient 's bowel was further prepared with p.o. erythromycin and neomycin base in one additional liter of Golytely . She experienced extreme nausea and vomiting with the erythromycin and neomycin . On December 3 , 1997 , the patient was taken to the Operating Room and under general anesthesia , she underwent an exploratory laparotomy , drainage of intraabdominal abscesses , and appendectomy by Dr. Zamorryn He . No ileocecectomy was performed . Cultures were taken of the peritoneal fluid . These peritoneal fluid cultures subsequently grew E. coli and coagulase negative Staphylococcus . The patient 's perioperative antibiotics ( ampicillin , Gentamicin , and Flagyl ) were continued . The patient tolerated the procedure well and was taken to the Recovery Room then subsequently to the floor . Pain service consultation was obtained for perioperative pain control and a patient controlled analgesia was begun . Patient 's nasogastric tube was discontinued on postoperative day one and by postoperative day two , the patient was out of bed and ambulating . On postoperative day three , the patient was started on oral sips and by postoperative day four , the patient was tolerating over a liter a day of clear liquids and had had one bowel movement . Her abdominal pain was dramatically decreased at this time . She had no abdominal distention and no erythema around the wound . Two Jackson-Pratts were placed intraoperatively . At the time of this dictation on postoperative day four , the Jackson-Pratts had put out under 5 cc of discharge per day . The patient is scheduled to be discharged tomorrow on December 8 , 1997 . Her Jackson-Pratt drains will be discontinued in the morning and the patient will be discharged on ofloxacin and Flagyl p.o. for a total antibiotic course of fourteen days which includes an additional nine days of antibiotics with the patient 's operative date being considered day one of antibiotics . DISPOSITION : Disposition is home without services . DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS : Ofloxacin 400 mg p.o. b.i.d. , Flagyl 500 mg p.o. t.i.d. , Colace 100 mg p.o. b.i.d. , and Percocet one to two tablets p.o. q.3-4h. p.r.n. pain . CONDITION ON DISCHARGE : Stable . FOLLOW-UP : Patient should follow-up with the An General Medical Center with Dr. Zamorryn Hanty He , he should call for an appointment within one week of discharge .
